inlineContent.text: The
makes use of many new features of Swift 5.7, including primary associated
types and constrained opaque types. If you are already using Swift 5.7+, then you can start making
use of these features right away. If you are using Swift 5.6 then you can still make use of
, but with a few minor tweaks.
The
type that allows you to construct a reducer from a closure, and has been around
since the very first version of the library, is now officially considered “soft-deprecated.” This
means that it will not show deprecation warnings in your code yet, but some day in the future we
will mark it deprecated, and then someday later remove the type from the library. This process will
take place over a long period of time, giving everyone enough time to migrate their applications.
There are a few strategies you can follow to slowly convert all usages of
to the new
protocol-style reducers. It does not need to be done all at once, and instead can be done in a
piecemeal fashion.
The simplest parts of an application to convert to
are leaf node features that
do not compose multiple reducers at once. For example, suppose you have a feature domain with a
dependency like this:
You can convert this to the protocol style by:
Creating a dedicated type that conforms to the
Nest the state and action types inside this new type, and rename them to just
and
Move the fields on the environment to be fields on this new reducer type, and delete the
environment type.
Move the reducer’s closure implementation to the
method.
Performing these 4 steps on the feature produces the following:

code: func reduce(into state: inout State, action: Action) -> Effect<Action, Never> {

inlineContent.text: Once this feature’s domain and reducer is converted to the new style you will invariably have
compiler errors wherever you were referring to the old types. For example, suppose you have a
parent feature that is currently trying to embed the old-style domain and reducer into its domain
and reducer:
This can be updated to work with the new
reducer conformance by first fixing any
references to the state and action types:
And then the
can be fixed by making use of the helper
which
aids in converting protocol-style reducers into old-style reducers. It is initialized with a closure
that is passed an environment, which is the one thing protocol-style reducers don’t have, and you
are to return a protocol-style reducer:
Note that the
’s only purpose is to convert the new-style reducer to the old-style
so that it can be plugged into existing old-style reducers. You can then chain on the operators
you were using before to the end of the
usage.
With those few changes your application should now build, and you have successfully converted one
leaf node feature to the new style of
Some features in your application are an amalgamation of other features. For example, a tab-based
application may have a separate domain and reducer for each tab, and then a app-level domain and
reducer that composes everything together.
Suppose that all of the tab features have already be converted to the protocol-style:

code: func reduce(into state: inout State, action: Action) -> Effect<Action, Never> {

inlineContent.text: But, suppose that the app-level domain and reducer has not yet be converted and so has compiler
errors due to referencing types and values that no longer exist:
To convert this to the protocol-style we again introduce a new type that conforms to the
, we nest the domain types inside the conformance, we inline the environment
fields, but this time we use the
requirement of the
protocol to describe how to compose multiple reducers:
With those few small changes we have now converted a composition of many reducers into the new
protocol-style.
A common pattern in the Composable Architecture is to model a feature that can be presented and
dismissed as optional state. For example, suppose you have the feature’s domain and reducer modeled
like so:
Then, the parent feature can embed this child feature as an optional in its state:
A non-
value for
indicates that the feature view is being presented, and when it
switches to
the view should be dismissed.
In order to construct a single reducer that can handle the logic for the parent domain as well as
allow the feature to run its logic on the
state when non-
, we can make use the
and
operators:
It seems complex, but we have now combined the logic for the parent feature and child feature into
one package, and the child feature will only run when the state is non-
Migrating the
to the protocol by following the earlier instructions will
yield a new
type that conforms to
, and the
will
look something like this:
Now the question is, how do we migrate
to a protocol conformance?
This gives us an opportunity to improve the correctness of this code. It turns out there is a gotcha
with the
operator: it must be run
before
the parent logic runs. If it is  not, then it
is possible for a child action to come into the system, the parent observe the action  and decide to
out the child state, and then the child  reducer will not get a chance to react to the action.
This can cause subtle bugs, and so we have documentation advising you to order things  the correct
way, and if we detect a child action while state is
we display a runtime warning.
A
reducer conformances can be made by implementing the
property of the
, which allows you
to express the parent’s logic as a composition of multiple reducers. In particular, you can use
the
entry point to implement the core parent logic, and then chain on the
operator to identify the optional child
state that you want to run the
reducer on when non-
Because the
operator has knowledge of both the parent and child reducers it can enforce the
order to add an additional layer of correctness.
If you are using an enum to model your state, then there is a corresponding
operator that can help you run a
reducer on just one case of the enum.
Similar to
reducers, another common pattern in applications is the use of the
to allow running a reducer
on each element of a collection. Converting such child and parent reducers will look nearly
identical to what we did above for optional reducers, but it will make use of the new
operator instead.
In particular, the new
method operates on the parent reducer by specifying the collection
sub-state you want to work on, and providing the element reducer you want to be able to run on
each element:
In the previous sections we inlined all dependencies directly into the conforming type:
But this means that you must explicitly thread all dependencies from the root of the application
through to every child feature. This can be arduous and make it difficult to add, remove or change
dependencies.
The library comes with a tool for managing dependencies in a more ergonomic manner, and even comes
with some common dependencies pre-integrated allowing you to access them with no additional work.
For example, the
dependency ships with the library so that you can declare your feature’s
dependence on that functionality in the following way:
With that one declaration you can stop explicitly passing the date dependency through every layer
of your application. A date function will be automatically provided to your feature’s reducer.
For domain-specific dependencies you can perform a little bit of upfront work to register your
dependency with the system, and then it will be automatically available to every layer in your
application:
With that work done you can access the dependency from any feature’s reducer using the
property wrapper:
For more information on designing your dependencies and providing live and test dependencies, see
our
article.
Stores can be initialized from an initial state and an instance of a type conforming to
Views that hold onto stores can also employ the
type alias to clean up the property
declaration:
Test stores can be initialized from an initial state and an instance of a type conforming to
By default test stores will employ “test” dependencies wherever a dependency is accessed from a
reducer via the
property wrapper.
Instead of passing an environment of test dependencies to the store, or mutating the store’s
, you will instead mutate the test store’s
to
override dependencies driving a feature.
For example, to install a test scheduler as the main queue dependency:

content.text: Embedding old reducer values in a new reducer conformance

inlineContent.text: It may not be feasible to migrate your entire application at once, and you may find yourself
needing to compose an existing value of
into a type conforming to
This can be done by passing the value and its environment of dependencies to
For example, suppose a tab of your application has not yet been converted to the protocol-style of
reducers, and it has an environment of dependencies:
It can still be embedded in
using
and passing along the
necessary dependencies.
The migration strategy described above for Swift 5.7 also applies to applications that are still
using Xcode 13 and Swift 5.6, but with one small change. When conforming your types to the
you are not allowed to use the
syntax
because that is only available in Swift 5.7. Instead, you must specify
as the type of the
property:
The
type is like a type-erased reducer that allows you to construct a reducer from a
closure. In Swift 5.6, the
will automatically erase the reducer you build for
you so that you do not have to worry about specifying its type explicitly. This may come with a
slight performance cost compared to using full opaque types for
, but should be of comparable
performance to reducers using the
type, which is now soft-deprecated.
All other features of the library should work in Swift 5.6 without any other changes. This includes
and all dependency management tools.

abstract.text: Learn how to migrate existing applications to use the new
, in both Swift 5.7 and
Swift 5.6.
The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
A non-existent body.
A version of
that transforms a reducer that works on
an element into one that works on an identified array of elements.
Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain that works on an optional property of parent state.
The current dependencies.
A type-erased reducer that invokes the given
function.
A convenience type alias for referring to a store of a given reducer’s domain.
A reducer describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state, given
an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if any.
Transforms a reducer that works on non-optional state into one that works on optional state by
only running the non-optional reducer when state is non-nil.
The
type encapsulates a unit of work that can be run in the outside world, and can
feed data back to the
. It is the perfect place to do side effects, such as network
requests, saving/loading from disk, creating timers, interacting with dependencies, and more.
The current environment.
Learn how to write comprehensive and exhaustive tests for your features built in the Composable
Architecture.
Learn how to write safe, concurrent effects using Swift’s structured concurrency.
Transforms a reducer that works on child state, action, and environment into one that works on
parent state, action and environment. It accomplishes this by providing 3 transformations to
the method:
Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain that works on a case of parent state.
A protocol that describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state,
given an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if any.
Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain that works on elements of a collection in parent
state.
